author: nick909

title: Mine Cart for LEGO Train scale to Minecraft toy Steve.

description.text:
I wanted a Mine Cart that Steve could ride in so I made one that fits a LEGO train. The Mine Cart plugs on the top of the motorized train engine so you can make it go on the tracks.
Steve and his chest will fit in the cart. You can put any block in the cart.
This is a work in progress.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Kh8XZlD6kM
Another train to use with Minecraft is an older train made in Germany by Fuller. The scale and shape fit well with the Minecraft figures.
I will be making a 3d printable train to add onto the LEGO train for Steve and his friends to ride.

I made 2 different sizes. One is just taller than the other.
Just print and make sure the hole in the center is big enough to snap on the LEGO train engine.
Pop it on and add Steve and any block and you are ready to go.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117519 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=117519

Using the following options: Text_Font = write/Letters.dxf
Text_Rotate = 0
Text_Size = 5
Your_Text = Eric & Angel

Bongo Tuning Head Bracket replacement part.
The original Chromed Tuning Head brackets were made of die-cast metal, extremely thin in places. This is now deteriorating and going brittle, like biscuit.
One has already shattered, and others will not last long, so I made a replacement.

To be honest, I could get a cheap set of Bongos for about £25, but wanted to keep these going a bit longer.

Remove all support material.
Mounting posts/Lugs may require some filing down depending on your Bongo mounting holes.
Drill the Mounting posts/Lugs to accept the original mounting screws/bolts.

This is a hydroponic trough drain for rectangular trough NTF systems http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nutrient_film_technique . It's also useful for draining tubs and barrels and uses a standard (even in this metric world) 3/4" BSP threaded section which is just over 1" (26mm) in diameter. There's little logic in those thread naming conventions! On the pointy end there is a 1/2" (13mm) barb for poking into the drainage tube of aforementioned diameter. Helps to warm the tube in hot water or the sun before fitting the barb. Fit with an appropriate washer from the hardware store, or squirt a bead of instant gasket on the flange of the drain before screwing it all together. (The nut thread has been tightened up a little in this new version). This one is printed in Diamond Age PLA, which in non-toxic and lasts well in hydroponic systems.

Make sure the barb is nice and smooth to avoid leaks. Run a flame or fine grit sandpaper over it if it looks a bit lumpy or stripey. Sometimes it helps to wrap the barb in PTFE threadseal tape if it's a bit slack. If you're building from scratch with OpenSCAD, download Dan Kirshner's threads.scad library first and comment out the metric example at the beginning:
https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel/blob/master/threads.scad (Is this on thingiverse? Can't find it) The one in the photo was printed on a DiamondMind V2 with a 0.45mm nozzle and 0.28mm layer height.

author: millemnm

title: Heart Pendant Created in ImplicitCAD with Python Scripting

description.text:
I created this pendant in ImplicitCAD using a Python script. I wanted to make a piece that would be castable and unique. This pendant is derived from the following parametric equation for a heart:
X(t) = 16sin^3(t)
Y(t) = 13cos(t) - 5cos(2t) - 2cos(3t) - cos(4*t)
(Ref: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8082429/plot-a-heart-in-r) I then wrote a recursive function in Python to generate a pattern of holes that seemed effervescent. I originally started this project with OpenSCAD (which is a fantastic program), however it proved difficult to create rounded edges. ImplicitCAD has a much simpler method for creating rounded edges. The language is similar to OpenSCAD, and I like the idea of scriptable CAD in general.

This thing can be generated by running heart.escad in ImplicitCAD.  
heart.escad is generated by myHeart.py, which draws the polygon for the heart shape and creates the hole pattern.  
Of course, the finished STL file is also provided, which may be printed or cast.

comments.text: Well, to be honest... I cheated and had a company called Kraftwurx cast the part for me. If I were to have done it myself, I'd have created a mould with plaster of paris and sand using a part printed in PLA.

I think it's usually easier to reduce the resolution than to increase it, so I provided a file with a very high resolution.

A calling card with working planetary gears. Astound your friends, frustrate your nemisii.
(Update: I've moved the gears slightly to the right, reducing the number of cut parts to assemble.)

Cut from card or bristol and assemble like a sandwich.  The middle layer needs to be appreciably thicker than the others; I cut it twice and glued the bits together, but I recommend using thicker paper board.  To keep the planetary teeth gears from getting caught up in the window edges, bend the gear teeth down (towards the back layer) slightly before assembly.  Glue down the middle (sun) gear only.  You can put three or four planetary gears inside.  It's a bit tricky to assemble; a spare pair of hands helps.  Good luck!

title: DLP Resin Printer Build Plate Adapter - fits LittleRP and SeeMeCNC

description.text:
This plate is designed to connect to LittleRP and SeeMeCNC DLP resin build plates to a printer that I've designed. The 'stock' SeeMeCNC plate for the DropLit uses a single center hole for mounting, but it turns out that there are vent holes at the same spacing as the 30x40mm mounting pattern as the LittleRP plates, so tapping the DropLit plate and flipping it over will allow you to use this design on either model of plate.

This mounting block has holes for M4 cap screws to attach the aluminum plate, and a center hole for an M8 cap screw for mounting to the leveling block.

Drawn with DesignSpark Mechanical - RSDOC source is included.

title: Mr Poopybutthole

description.text:
Not my work at all. These are designed by 3DPrintGuy: http://www.3dprintguy.co/ and made available for free on the Rick & Morty facebook page.

Originals: http://asw.im/512Mog

The only modification that I've made is that I used 123D Design to rotate the models 90 degrees.

Legs are very thin so print with high infill and be careful when removing supports. You may want to print it bigger if you want it less fragile.

0.2mm, supports and 50% infill did the trick for me. First try at 0.3mm and 10% infall was to fragile and broke when removing supports.

Later I scaled the models to 150% and printed (white prints) with 0.2mm and 30% infill and it turned out great and much less fragile than the unscaled versions (yellow prints).

title: Ikea Samla Clip. The best one. Period. (5.11.22.45.65 Liter)

description.text:
NEW! Now also in 45/65 Liter version.
––––
I know „The best one“ sounds arrogant and bold, but let me explain:

You can find quite a few locking clip designs for the Ikea Samla boxes here on Thingiverse, but most of them just don't work as satisfying as they should. I've tested them all and found that they are either too small, too massive, don't snap securely, slide/slip, interfere on stacking or simply can't be grabbed/handled properly. Interestingly even the original clips Ikea itself offers suck (they seriously do).

Being a, what I call, pixel f*cker, I made no less than 10 (!) revisions, tweaking dimensions in steps of tenths of millimeters, and playing with various degrees of pretension, until I came up with the perfect clip, one which really works as one would expect:

• Excellent thumb handling
• Tight and secure grip with satisfying snap
• Correct stiffness vs. flexibility ratio: As thick as necessary, as thin as possible
• No interference on stacking.
• Versions for 5/11/22 Liter and 45/65 Liter boxes.
• Harmonically rounded, so actually also good looking. Also feels good.

Save your time and filament, skip the mediocre experience with other designs and go with this clip. Satisfaction guaranteed!

Adjustable in length

The clip is based on a simple extrusion, which means you can scale the length as desired. It has been initially designed with 36 mm in length (which is what you see in the preview), but snaps and handles just as good and tight, at 22 mm. I wouldn't go any shorter than that however, as it then becomes inconvenient to grab with the thumb on opening.

Print orientation

Place sideways on your print bed, so clips get printed in extrusion direction.

If you are satisfied and print more than two of my clips, I'd appreciate a small donation of a $/€ or two through the blue TIP BUTTON on the left.

Thanks and enjoy,
André

title: Knock Off NES Controller PiZero Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Full instructions in the video.
I wanted to be able to use the original case created by Brandon Fesser (linked in remixed from) with a knock off controller rather than a legit one. Problem was it didnt fit.
https://youtu.be/BXlx3dGfUNs

Printed at .2 layer height
No supports needed even with my crappy CTC :-)

bfesser (original creator notes)
"Hey, nice work on the remix! I designed the screw holes to be opened up with a #45 (2.0828mm) drill after printing, but you can just add 0.25 mm to the hole diameter in the model for printed-in clearance."

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2A8HAh5qJUq

comments.text: Hey, nice work on the remix!  I designed the screw holes to be opened up with a #45 (2.0828mm) drill after printing, but you can just add 0.25 mm to the hole diameter in the model for printed-in clearance.

This is my first tank from 2017 made from scratch ( Not an improvement from a previous model) However, it used components from my Chieftain design, such as the tracks. other than that, it is completely new.

I modeled an anatomical heart off of a scientific website in sculpy and scanned that into the computer. Due to the unique shape and variety of forms on each side, I had very little problems editing it for printing

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 Mk8 Fan Cooler Mount by 3D Monkey(s) Lab.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fan Cooler system for Geeetech Prusa i3 with Mk8. Remixed from 3 different fan mount to make a complete kit for the mk8 extruder.

The cooler is in 2 parts so that you can adjust the height of the hesine for your perfect fit. For me it was too long so I cutted a little bit the hesine and I attacked pieces togheter with glue and a strap of tape to be sure that no air will go out. Be sure that the cooler will not touch the bed or the x-axe carriage while homing. I printed the reverse option of the fan grid cause original screws wasn't long enough to fit all pieces, so I used original long screws to lock togheter fan, cooler and mk8 and 2 short screws to tight the grid to the fan in upper free holes of the fan. Enjoy :)

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

10%

comments.text:
I love this design but the model is full of flaws after slicing using S3D. Is this dependent on slicer?
it's full of holes near the logo and the duct is half blocked due to unnecessary 3d block inside the duct on the model.
I tried removing blockage and patched the holes but it's too difficult for my amateur 3d drawing skill.
Also it would be good if the two parts can slot together without tapes.
The complete model is impossible to print due to this massive overhang.
comments.author: gti96

comments.text: El interior del Cooler_Head_Prusa_i3 tiene defectos y no permite que el aire circule con lfuides, La idea es buena igual. Gracias por el aporte

description.text:
This dice is a ball outside and has a hollow octaeder inside.
In the octaeder cave there is a steel ball, that you have to fit
before glueing the half shells.

The size is designed for a 8 mm steel ball, scale to another ball size if necessary.

How to use:
Throw it like a normal dice, it will always stop with points (1 to 6) up, despite
being a ball shape outside.

For those, who don't want to glue two half shells but instead want to interrupt the print for insertion of the steel ball, I've added an stl with the dice as a whole.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1mm
Glue two dice halfs together, attention to fit the points
ProE

comments.text: Can you post a .stl file with both halves already joined together?   I'd print it with a bit of support, then pause the printing once the top  of the cavity is still large enough to drop in the 8mm steel ball. Then resume printing to enclose the steel ball.    There would be no need to glue the halves together.

title: Tevo Black Widow auto-level sensor mount

description.text:
mount for adding an inductive or capacitance sensor to the Tevo Black Widow. This mount places the sensor approximately 30mm to the right and 16mm in front of the nozzle.

*added a v2 mount that works with my extruder spacer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2188117

I used a LJC18A3-H-Z/BX sensor, and connected as follows:

BLUE (-) to PSU ground
BROWN (+) to PSU +24v
BLACK (sensor output) to a 1N4001* diode (anode) then diode (cathode) to Z MIN input on controller (black wire).

I just cut the wires to the original end stop and soldered the sensor to the black wire on the connector.

*if you're worried about the voltage from the sensor causing damage to the controller, you can use a 5v zener diode instead.

NOTE If you're using a glass sheet on top of the heated metal bed, like I do, this sensor DOES NOT detect the glass, but the metal bed under the glass. You can get it to detect the glass if you turn the sensitivity up high enough, but even then, it will still detect the metal bed under the glass before actually detecting the glass. Make sure you set your leveling points to the most flat spots on the metal bed. My bed is pretty badly warped, but I was able to find 3 spots that give me a nice level surface when running the auto-leveling.

Here's the modified firmware I'm using with the sensor. I just added an option in Configuration.h, "PROXIMITY_SENSOR" where, if defined, will enable the sensor. You will see "Black Widow PS" displayed on the LCD if it is enabled. This is a version of the firmware that was already modified by Robert Mendon for use with the BLTouch. It is available on the TEVO Black Widow Owners Group on FaceBook.

https://www.dropbox.com/sh/4nuyhwvtw3i0ch9/AACHwd1uls0ZtAQt4xrei2-Xa?dl=0

**Be sure to set your probe positions and auto-leveling positions in the firmware. The values I'm using might not work for everyone.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

No

No

description.text:
Compact fan mount for E3D with LED's

U need:
1 x 40mm fan
2 x 5015 fan
3 x 5mm LED's
1 resistor
I use a fan controller for my fans and you gonna need that for this since 2x5015 moves a lot of air.
At full speed this will cool down the hotend so fan controller is a must.
I made this so i can slow down fans and reduce noise.

This slides over the heatsink. Dont try to push it straight on or it will break.

EDIT: added a version without holes for LED's
And a single side version.
With this carrier the wirering will be gathered in the middle and clean up the look. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2117446

This is made from 2 existing files here at Thingiverse

For the LED's ive used 3 x 5mm white and a resistor.
Used a LED calculator to figure out the value of the resistor.

Description

These parts are used to make Scalar 3D printers compatible with DUal extrusion.

Dual extrusion is made using a "Y" like convector.
This system is based on the idea from "distechautomation" who is making the Prometheus Hotend providing a dual extrusion system using 1 single hotend.
The idea was then taken back by Prusa Research and improved to 4 color system using a multiplexer board. The multiplexer board makes it possible to use this system with 4 extruders using a standard Ramps 1.4 board and a single stepper motor driver!

We redesigned the system for a simple 2 extruders system so that it can fit our Scalar 3D printers.

Compatibility

These parts are compatible with 1.75mm filament only for now.
It was tested using E3D Lite hotend.

What you need

  • 2 Pneufit connectors ( http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/mechanical/223-m6-push-to-fit-pneufit-connector-for-4mm-od-ptfe-tubes-compatible-with-175mm-filament.html )
  • 2 PTFE tubes for 1.75mm filament (length depends on where you place your extruders) (http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/mechanical/152-black-ptfe-tube-for-3mm-3d-printer-filament.html)
  • A few Thermoplastic Screws (M3x8 and M3x16)
  • a few M6x12 and Tnuts for extruder holders on extrusion profiles.
  • 1 extra extruder and Drive gear.

How it works

The filament will converge into 1 single output.
So your extruder will push 1 filament into the hot end, then during color change the current filament will fully be retracted from the hot end and the second filament will be pushed into the hot end.

You might need to apply more than 100mm of retraction so that the filament is fully extracted from the tubing system into the Y plastic parts.

You will need to insert the tubes from extruder into the "Y3 plastic parts up to the middle of it.

On the exit you need to make sure that the PTFE tube that goes inside the hotend is also entering the exit of the "Y" plastic part. (there is a special groove for it).

Also make sure the PTFE tube coming from the hotend is grooved with some conic tool (a crew driver or something similar) in order to create an entering cone into the PTFE tube.

About the provided holder it should fit on top of the hot end mount from Scalar 3D printers.

Existing Multi color units

Here is a cool one using 5 colors:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2403517 thanks to sportssedan for sharing !

That is very cool! thanks for sharing!

comments.author: sportssedan

comments.text:
Hi , Yes no problems to share the link .
I use it every day as i design & sell various printed parts on Ebay . As mentioned in the part description , i don't use it for multi-color prints , as i'm still using a standard motherboard ( single extruder) I just use it so that i have 5 colors loaded & ready to go . I have a similar code to your description where i do a 120mm E retraction in the End Gcode , so that the printed filament clears the convergence manifold after printing .
When i want to start the next print i just select the color by plugging in whichever extruder i need. Sounds a bit basic & i was going to upgrade motherboards etc , but for my needs its just so easy to plug in the extruder color i need & get on with it.
I wrote a script & ran some tests with multiple retraction & feeds & made a video which is in the description. It works best with ABS as very little stringing , but i managed to get it working with PETG , & the video was all PETG filaments , however unless its set right the stringing may become a problem , but that will be the same with any convergence design .
Hope some people find it useful.
P.s , had a look at your designs , you've got some nice engineering happening there!! .

title: BLE MIDI Controller with Capacitive Touch Pads

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X1cI5xkjVC8

In this guide, I'll show you how I built this strange looking MIDI controller. It doesn't look like your typical drum pad or keyboard, but it does have similar functionality just like any standard MIDI controller. It features six capacitive touch pads that trigger MIDI notes. Tap one of the pads, and it plays a note. It also features a step sequencer so you can record and playback a pattern. The 16 NeoPixel ring displays a glowing dot for each step which also follows the beat of a given tempo. It can also change settings, such as pitch, tempo, shuffle, length, velocity and even MIDI channel.

Full Learning Guide:
https://learn.adafruit.com/bluetooth-le-midi-controller/overview

comments.text: Love it.  Thanks for the inspiration AdaFruit!  I'm going ahead with a substantial Remix, as I had some ideas to make it even more interesting.  Parts ordered from AdaFruit and modeling in progress.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: Hi, there! I'd say the most "finicky" part of the build is wiring up the capacitive touch pads. Keeping the wires secured to them can be challenging. If you plan on using conductive PLA, you'll need to use something like bare conductive paint to "glue" the wires to the pads – just be patient and allow the paint to fully set and dry.
